description: Surface analysis pan- + psychism. From German Panpsychismus (1874), from Latin pampsychia (1591). Cognate with Ancient Greek πάμψυχος (pámpsukhos, “in full life”) and (modern) Greek παμψυχισμός (pampsychismós, “panpsychism”).

entries.meaning: (philosophy, metaphysics, uncountable) The doctrine that all matter has a mental aspect.
examples: Pansychists often qualify panpsychism so that only "true individuals" are animated: i.e., so that things like atoms, molecules, and organisms are animated as atoms, molecules, and organisms, whereas things like rocks, tables, and boots are not animated as themselves, although they do comprise animate elements (e.g., molecules).

entries.meaning: (philosophy, metaphysics, countable) Any specific doctrine or system of panpsychism.
examples: Whitehead devised such a conception, which to my mind definitely supersedes the panpsychisms of the history of metaphysics.
